name: Wroclaw
fun_fact: Fun fact: Wroclaw has over 350 small bronze dwarf statues (krasnale) hidden throughout the city - a treasure hunt tradition started as an anti-communist protest in the 1980s. The city sits on 12 islands connected by 112 bridges, earning it the nickname 'Venice of Poland.'

hero_dishes.name: Pierogi Ruskie
hero_dishes.description: Boiled dumplings filled with potato, farmer's cheese, and fried onions - served with sour cream and more fried onions
hero_dishes.origin_story: Despite the name 'ruskie' (Russian), these are quintessentially Polish. The filling combines mashed potatoes with twarÃ³g (farmer's cheese) and caramelized onions. Each Polish grandmother claims the best recipe. Wroclaw's pierogi culture is serious - locals debate endlessly about the perfect potato-to-cheese ratio.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Pierogarnia Stary MÅ‚yn, milk bars (bar mleczny) throughout Wroclaw, or traditional Polish restaurants in the Market Square area

hero_dishes.origin_story: Made from fermented rye flour, Å¼urek has medieval origins. The sour tang comes from days of fermentation. Wroclaw residents eat it year-round, but especially at Easter. The bread bowl (not always used) is edible - soup-soaked bread is the best part. It's hangover cure and comfort food in one.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional Polish restaurants in Wroclaw Old Town, Gospoda Lwowska, or Konspira restaurant

hero_dishes.name: ÅšlÄ…skie ModÅ‚y (Silesian Dumplings)
hero_dishes.description: Large potato dumplings with a distinctive indentation in the middle, served with gravy and meat
hero_dishes.origin_story: Specific to Silesia region (Wroclaw's region), these dumplings differ from regular kopytka. The thumb indentation holds gravy. Silesian families eat them with rouladen (beef rolls) or goulash. They're labor-intensive to make - a sign of love when homemade.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Silesian restaurants in Wroclaw, or traditional Polish eateries

hero_dishes.origin_story: Eaten year-round but especially on Fat Thursday (TÅ‚usty Czwartek) before Lent when Poles consume millions. The traditional filling is rose jam, though modern versions use custard or chocolate. Wroclaw bakeries sell them fresh-made. Eating just one is nearly impossible.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Bakeries throughout Wroclaw, especially on Fat Thursday (Thursday before Ash Wednesday)

signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Poles drink Å›liwowica as digestif after heavy meals or during celebrations. It's sipped neat from small glasses. signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Wroclaw has vibrant beer culture with brewpubs and beer gardens. Locals drink Polish lagers (Tyskie, Å»ywiec, Lech) in pubs along the Odra River or at the Market Square. Beer pairs with every Polish dish - the mild flavor doesn't compete with garlic and onions.

Market Square (Rynek) is medieval Europe's second-largest square after Krakow - surrounded by restaurants
Wroclaw's German past (Breslau) shows in some dishes and beer culture
